2.title: Structure of the Upaniṣad and Jyotir Brāhmaṇa Introduction
2.content: Thank you. So last year we have covered the first chapter as well as the second chapter. First chapter was pertaining to Avidya. It had six Brahmanas as well as second chapter when you see that also had six Brahmanas. And this year particularly you have seen the third chapter which is under

3.title: Janaka–Yājñavalkya Dialogue – “Kim Jyotiḥ ayam puruṣaḥ?”
3.content:
Munikanda.

These six chapters of Brihadaranya Upanishad are divided into three different Kandas or you can say sections, portions or categories. So first one is Madhukanda, which is first two chapters. Second one, the third and fourth chapter comes under Monikanda, which is considered to be the most important. And third one, it will be seen, Khilakanda, which is the chapter fifth and sixth.

So under Monikanda, third chapter is already completed. And the two first two Brahmanas of fourth chapter is also completed by the Acharyas. Now we'll be seeing the third Brahmana of the fourth chapter, named Jyotir Brahmana.

And whatever was covered into the previous chapters and previous Brahmanas etc., we will be seeing, Bhagawan Bhashyakara will be giving an introduction as well as Anand Giri, the commentary. Those who are attending the first class of Upanishad, this is one among the most advanced Upanishads named Brihadaranya. Brihad means very vast in size.

Aranya is like a forest. It's very little bit complicated. So to understand it, you have to pay attention.

That's the general common meaning of Brahadaranya. So whatever was covered previously will be said by Bhagawan Bhashyakar as well as the main commentator, Bhagawan Adi Shankaracharya, as well as the sub-commentary on it is called Anand Giri, that we will be seeing. Why there was a need to further continue when the discussion was already over in the previous brahmanas, what was the purpose to continue, there it will be said, all these things. But first, when you see the handouts and leaflets which are given, so there are some additional things apart from the commentary as well as the Moola transliteration shlokas.

One among them is the names of all the brahmanas in the six chapters. That's just for the reference. That if someone asks you, what are the names of the brahmanas you have completed, Brihadar and Yopanishad, I will see if you want to refer.

So this is handy, you can say. Second one will you see, Or I don't know how it is pinned over there. But Bhagwan Bhashyakara has written a single shloka.

Why this is necessary when we cover here? The Brahmana which we are going to start is what? Jyotir Brahmana.

Jyoti means light. Now, what kind of light are we talking about? What is the purpose here when we are talking about the Atma Vidya?

What is the purpose of the light here? So you will see in this particular Brahmana that Yagyavalkya will one fine day, he will go to

4.title: Four Activities – Āste, Paryeti, Karma Kurute, Viparyeti
4.content:
Janaka, the king. And there, without even offering him any namaskara or seat or anything, the first question Janaka will be saying, asking to Yagya Valkya is, "Kim jyoti rayam purusha heti?" What is the jyoti?

What is that light through which this Purusha functions? And there are

5.title: Eka Ślokī Discussion
5.content:
four activities which will be said, "Aaste, palyate, karma kurute, vipalyate." These are the four activities. "Aaste" means his sitting.

You see, wherever there is an activity you see in this particular physical body or whatever, there needs some light. Light, what is that kind of light which we will be seeing in further this Jyoti Brahmana? But these are the four activities. Aasthe means he is sitting. Even if you think you are not doing any activity, you are just sitting.

Sitting in itself is called an activity. And then Palyayate. Palyayate means moving around or going for some work. Then the third is karmakurute, performing any task or activity after going there. And vipalyeti, vipalyeti means coming back.

These are the four activities. What is that light through which a person functions? Then it will be seen in the whole Jyotir Brahmana.

But here Bhagwan Bhashyakara or Adi Shankaracharya has written a very very beautiful, only one single shloka, but it is called

6.title: Purpose of Light – From Gross to Subtle
6.content:
Ekashloki. So if you have this, I think everybody has it. You please, you can see. So this is a discussion between a guru and a disciple. So it is a very beautiful shloka.

If you are able to chant it or if you are able to follow it, it would be good. It says, kimjotisthava bhanumana hanime, ratraupradipadikam syadevamravidipadarshanavidhav kimjotirakhyahime, chakshustasya nimilanadi samaye, So what it says, the Guru asks, the Master, the teacher asks, "Kimjyoti stava?" Till there, there is a question. If you want to put, you can put a question mark. "Kimjyoti?" What is that light? "Tava" means yours.

What is that light through which you function? What is that light of yours? Then the reply comes, the sun itself is the light for me through which I function. Ahani means what?

During the daytime. In the absence of sun, During the night, then, "rātrau pradipādikam" - "rātrau" means in the night, "pradipa" means the lamp, "ādi" means etc., alternate source of lights, "pradipādikam". Then the Guru says, this was the reply from the disciple. Then the Guru says, Syaadevam, let it be.

Okay, I agree to your answer. But what is the light through which you are seeing the sun as well as the lamp? Ravi Deepa Darshan Vidau Kim Jyoti Aakhyai Me Tell me what is that light through which you are seeing the sun and the lamp etc.?

Then what will be the reply? Normal, common reply according to your intellect, what it is? "Chakshuhu" - the eye through which you are seeing.

If there is a sun, if there is a lamp, but if there is no eyes or if there is no light in the eye, will it be possible to see the sun or the lamp etc.? So the disciple says, "Chakshuhu" - the eye is the light. "Tasyanimilyanadi samaye" - what happens if the eyes are closed?

Close means either in the dream state or the deep sleep or probably even in the waking state if you are meditating or if someone does not have the light or the power in the eye. What is that? What is that light then?

Then it is said intellect. Then what is the light? through which you are seeing the intellect, through which you are understanding the intellect, then there is no other light except me.

That I, what you say, is the final, is the absolute, is the supreme light it is called. 'Tatra aham' 'Bhavan paramakam' 'Paramakam' means the supreme height. 'Jyotisthadasmi Prabhu' I am the light.

So what we are going to cover in this Jyotish Brahmana is being explained by Bhagawan Bhashyakaara in one simple shloka. We will be starting from the grossest going to the subtlest. These four lines gives you an idea that what we are going to cover in this Jyotir Brahmana. So this is very, very beautiful shloka and very important to understand.

Then you will be seeing, that there is an additional leaflet which is called Shalindas. Those who are already attending the Vedanta classes from years, they have the Samskaras impressions. So all this which we are talking, it is not about them, it is not for them, but those who are attending the Vedanta classes first time, there may be some, I don't know, but for them this is.

You see, to understand a subject, any subject what we are going to study, there are some Linga means what? You must have heard about Shiva Linga or that which reveals a very secretive meaning is called Linga. So here also when you talk about it, Shad is called six and

7.title: Ṣaḍ-Liṅga Method – Upakrama to Phala
7.content:
Shad Linga, there are six signs.

and Sri Swami Sivanandaji Maharaj has explained, you can see the leaflet, that to understand a subject, these are the six signs or marks through which you have to understand a subject. So, it is called Upakrama and Upasamhara. The commencement and the conclusion should be in one line.

It is not that you have started talking about a some particular subject or topic and you are ending it somewhere. That does not happen. So the commencement and conclusion should be in one line.

That is called 'upakrama' and 'upasambhara'. Then 'abhyasa'. The topic, the subject is so complicated, so 'klista'. that even when you have studied different kind of Upanishads in Chandogya, how many times Shwetaket was instructed by his father? Nine times.

So here also the Abhyasa. Abhyasa is called practice. not to understand as repetition, but it is called practice.

Again and again and again you have to practice. So the scripture will be instructing the same teachings with various different kinds of Shrutis. Shrutis are the mantras, Ved mantras that is.

Then Apoorvata, you see to attract the mind, you need to say something, you need to show something which is unique. If whatever is already you are seeing in the world, if the scripture says the same, will you have a devotion towards the scripture? You say, this we already know.

Otherwise, what is the need? What is the purpose over there? So, apurvata is called unprecedentedness or uniqueness.

So, that you have to understand, apurvata. Then comes the phala. You say...

It is very very simple. No matter whether you have studied the scriptures or you have not studied the scriptures. It is very simple. People say, without giving, without showing the results, even a dullard will not engage in any activity. First of all, as soon as I tell you, will you do this for me?

Even a child asks, what will I get? That is the first question. So here also, the phala, phala is the result, end result you can say, that will be shown by the scriptures, that will be shown by the Shrutis, that if you are studying this, this is the end result of it, that is called phala or fruit. And then arthavadha, arthavadha is, It says explanatory statements or you can say Arthavada is praise. In a simple language when you talk about it, it's called praise.

Previously in the last year class we have seen what kind of different Arthavadas are there. Bhuta Arthavada, Yatha Arthavada etc. Those we have already covered.

But not to complicate the matter here further. Arthavada is just the praise. Then comes the Upapatti. Upapatti is illustrations. Through the process of illustrations, the subject, the topic will be explained.

So these are the six. Upakrama and Upasamhara is one. So when you count it, these are the six. Now how do they pertain in this particular chapter four?

This is given. When you go there, it is said, how does it commence? So, Upakrama is this you have already studied in the fourth chapter, second Brahmana, second mantra or Kandika it is called. Here in Brihadaranyopanishad, it is called Kandika.

So, what was it? Indo Havai Naama. When you see what was the name of the second Brahmana of the fourth chapter, go back to the chart.

It was Kurcha Brahmana. Did you get it in the chart? So, what was said?

Nicely forgotten. Those who have attended these classes during the month of January and February and March, what was the second Brahmana, Kurcha Brahmana, what was instructed there in the fourth chapter? Anybody? So it was said that during the process, by the process of showing waking, dream state and deep sleep, from starting from the grosses, taking into the subtlest, then the Turiya, Vishwata Ijasapragya and Turiya, all this were shown. for the purpose of moksha and krama mukti as well and paraloka it was said which will be covering here when we start it is said to go in the process by showing the dream state it will be shown that this body remains here but the jiva the one who is identifying with the eye the whole day since the morning when you wake up till you go to the sleep the thing what you are using as eye is not this particular body, this gross or subtle or causal body, but it is distinct from these three bodies that was shown in the Kurcha Brahmana by an example of waking state, dream state, deep sleep and fourth state that is Turiya.

So Indha is called in the right eye, this is the meditation. It is shown, those who have studied this second Brahmana, Kurcha Brahmana, if they remember, this is to be meditated in the right eye. Dakshinakshin Purusha, it is called.

And the name is Indha. So, Indho Vainama. This is how it commences. This is the Upakrama Upasamhara commencement of the whole fourth chapter.

So, it has already commenced in the second Brahmana, previous Brahmana. That is, Indho Vainama. And the page numbers are given there. If you have the book, you can go to 8:33 and you can see. Then that is a soft commencing.

But there is another commencing which will happen here in the fourth chapter, third Brahmana, second Kandika. It is called "kemjyoti rayam purushayati". Just now as we were saying, one fine day Yagya Valkya will be going to Janaka and without even offering any seat and etc., Janaka immediately will ask, What is the purpose? That will be shown.

There, previously there was a discussion between Yagyavalkya and Janaka. So Janaka has answered satisfactorily to all the questions of Yagyavalkya pertaining to the Agnihotra. So, then Agnihotra is the sacrifices and oblations offered. That is Agnihotra. So, pertaining to that Agnihotra, Yagyavalkya's questions were answered satisfactorily by King Janaka.

So, he has given a boon. Who? Yagyavalkya has given a boon to Janaka. And what was that boon?

You can ask. So, I am giving you a boon. So, what did Janaka say?

I want Kama Prashna. Kama Prashna means whenever I desire to ask a question, I can ask you. I should be able to ask you. That is the boon, Kama Prashna.

So that he will be utilizing here. So that is. So in the second mantra, when you see of this very particular Brahmana, that is Jyotir Brahmana, fourth chapter, third Brahmana, second Kandika, it is Kim Jyotirayam Purusha. What is that light within which you are talking about or external or internal?

Both of them will be discussed. External as you have seen already through our first loka, you can say sun is the light. In the absence of sun, there is a lamp etc. or moon, pradipadikam etc. So where does it go? Where does it, subtlest portion, where does it end?

All these things, this is the commencement of this particular topic or chapter. Then Upasamhara, the conclusion, where will it conclude? Savaesha Mahanaja Atma, going to the fourth Brahmana, which is the Brahmana which we are going to commence now? What is the name?

Jyotir Brahmana. So the conclusion will be in the fourth Brahmana, that is Shariraka Brahmana, in the 25th Kandika, it will be said, Savaesha Mahan Aja Atma. This Atma, the self which we are talking about, which the scriptures is teaching us, it is great, mahaan. Aja means what?

There is no birth. As soon as you say no birth, there is no death. In all the previous Upanishads we have seen, as soon as one Upadi comes, Aja, Amara, and Jarav Yukta, there is no old age, there is no death, there is no birth, etc.

All these things you have to understand about this self, which is within. And then, yatra tvasyasarvam ātmai bhag. Then second conclusion which we will say, that is, in the fifth brāhmaṇa, what is the fifth brāhmaṇa? Our all, everybody knows, that is, maitrei brāhmaṇa.

So there in the 15th kandika, it will be said, In the state where everything has become self, then who will be afraid of whom? What will he see? To whom will he see? When everything is self, then what will he see? By what he will see?

There is no triad. What is the triad? The one who is seeing, the medium through which one is seeing and This triputi it is called. Dhyata, one who is the meditating or one who is seeing or you can say and the medium through which it is seen, the mind, the intellect, the senses, the organs, that does not remain and the final, that is subject does not remain, to whom are you seeing? This triad is completely destroyed.

So that is being said in the fifth Brahmana, Maitreya Brahmana. Yatra tvasya sarvam atma hi vabhud, tat kenakam pashyet, tat kenakam jigret, tat kenakam shrunyat, tat kenakam vijaniyat, All these things will be told in the Maitreya Brahmana. But we have already seen those in the second chapter.

Fourth Brahmana is Maitreya Brahmana. There we have studied. But it will be told here also. When we go there, it will be explained why there was a need to again repeat this particular Ramanah, that is Maitreya Brahmanah. Then Abhyasah.

After seeing the conclusion, now the practice is, So this is all, it will come that, All these deities, the deities are not elsewhere when you try to find them. In the Upanishad, in the Vedanta, whenever you talk about the deities, what are those deities? The Deities pertaining to the sense organs, the Deities pertaining to the organs of activities, all these Deities, they worship that ultimate supreme all-pervading consciousness as Aayu.

Aayu is longevity. In this way, there will be couple of mantras. So these are called as practice. So the numbers are given as well as the page number according to the panoli is also given. You can go through it.

But we will anyhow cover them once we are there. Then comes 'apurvata' - unprecedentedness, something unique, apart from the other Upanishads as well as unique here. 'vijñatāramarekena vijāniyād ete' - this also comes under Maitreya Brahman, which we have seen in the previous second chapter. The one who is knowing everything, how will you know that?

You see, elsewhere it is said, That which is not known through the mind, but the mind knows through its power. How will you know that? It is behind each and every activity.

It is behind the mind, behind the intellect. The intellect is able to function only because of the power of that. Is it possible to see? No.

You cannot ever see the source of it. So that is what. So this is the unprecedentedness.

Then comes the phalam. What is the phalam? You see, as long as the desire remains in your mind so long, this cycle of birth and death will continue.

What Arjuna has asked in Srimad Bhagavad Gita, if you remember the second chapter, let's lighten up the subject. Gita everybody has studied, most of you. If you remember what Arjuna asked in the second chapter, "stitaprajyasya kaabhasha samadhisthasya keshava kimasitav rajetakhim" The one who is in his own self, the one who has reached the state of level of mind and maturity, How does he sit? How does he talk? How does he move around?

Then Lord Krishna answers, One who has given up all his desires are dissolved in his mind. There are no more desires in his mind. I should become such and such person or I should get this.

This should be mine and this is me. These are the only things which are functioning the whole, which are making this whole world function. If you think deeply, I am this and this is my responsibility. I should do this, this I need to do or I need to have this. So these are all desires.

As soon as you give up the desires, giving up is not as easy as we speak, but once the mind is purified, and once you know your own self, that is, then only it will come to such a stage, the state of maturity. So it is said, there are no more desires left in his mind. That is the phalam of this, this, this, this, that all these desires in the mind, they automatically, naturally dissolve. It's not that you are trying to enforce it. No matter how much you enforce, it doesn't happen.

it slightly in the mind, it immediately will creep up as long as there is no purification of Antahkarana. Antahkarana is mind, intellect, ego and Chitta, consciousness. These four constitutes the Antahkarana.

So only after the Antahkarana Shuddhi, when you have the Upadesha, teachings of the scriptures, of the knowledge, then only you reach to this particular state. So this is the Phalam. It will be told in The Shari Raka Brahmana itself, 446 to 448, that is the fruit. Then the Arthavadha, glorifying passage.

So it is said, "mṛtyoḥ sa mṛtyum āpnoti yaiha nāneva paśyati" What will happen? The one who has become one with the all-pervading consciousness, he will not see death. Here you have to understand, you see, when you see, when you read the meaning, As long as you are seeing many, so long you will be seeing the death. Death means what?

punar api jananam punar api maranam punar api janani jathare shayanam Again and again and again the cycle of birth and death will continue. As long as you are seeing nana. Nana means what? Many.

As soon as you see oneness, then there is no birth, no death. Whose birth will be? And whose death will it be? Because there is no other thing.

There is only one thing. As soon as you see the oneness. As far as you don't see the oneness, so long you will be seeing the death. So indirectly you have to understand here. So, mṛtyohasa mṛtyumāpnoti.

He will be again and again and again reaching to the door of death. Ya ihan ānīva paśyati. Ya one who sees as if there are many. You see, nāna iva. When you break this particular Sanskrit word, 'Nana Iva' means as if there are many.

But from the absolute state, there is no other thing. It is 'Advaitam'. How many of you remember what are the three kinds of states which we talk about? One is 'Paramarthika Satta' that is absolute state.

'Vyavarika' is empirical state. And 'Pratibhasika' that is illusionary state. So then comes the 'Upapatti' illustration. So, yadvaitanna pashyati, as long as it does not see, the one is so long, it will remain this.

So, this will be told in this very Brahmana in 23rd Kandika. Pranasya pranam uta, the one supreme conscious being is the vital air of the vital air. Pranasya pranam, chakshushas chakshuhu, it will be said there. So then, "navāre patyuh kāmāya pati priyo bhavati" This is again Maitreyi Brāhmaṇa.

It will be said, the husband is not dear for the sake of husband. Then whose sake is it dear? "ātmanas tu kāmāya sarvam priyam bhavati" It is dear for the sake of the self.

This we have seen in the fourth Brāhmaṇa, Maitreyi Brāhmaṇa of second chapter. But it will be said here as well. So these are the shuttling six signs to understand the subject. That is Upakrama, Upasamhara and etc.

Abhyasa, Purvata, Phalam, Arthavada and Upapatti. What else is remaining? So if someone asks you, what Upanishad are you studying currently?

Then you have to say, Brihadaranya. In which Veda has it occurred? Shukla Yajur Veda. How many recensions or branches? Each Veda has many, many recensions.

So here in Shukla Yajur Veda, how many you have? There were many. Currently available only two. That is, one is Kaanva. and second is Madhyandina.

So we are studying from what aspect? We are studying from the Kaanva Shakha. So this all you should know.

When you say, oh we have studied Brihadaranya immediately if someone asks or even for personal, your own knowledge you should know. So this is Kaanva Shakha Shukla Yajurvediya Brihadaranya Ko Upanishad. This is also called Vajasani Samhita.

Vajasani is the name of the sun. And this is the name of the father of Yagya Valkya. He is the primary Rishi of this Upanishad.

So he received this Vidya from the son. That is why it is called Shukla. Shukla is white Yajurveda.

And another reason this is Shukla Yajurveda is because the mantras here, they are not mixed with another explanation etc. When you see the Krishna Yajur Veda, the mantras which occur there in Krishna Yajur Veda, they are also along with the explanations and performance and etc. of the particular ritualistic portion. That is why it is called Mix Krishna, the Black Yajur Veda.

This is Shukla is only purity. So Shukla Yajur Veda Vajasane Samhita Kanva Shaka Brihadaranyaka Upanishad. In this way you should understand. So in the first Brahmana of this fourth chapter, the name was Shadacharya. So Yagyavalkya has received the teachings from six acharyas.

Sorry, Janaka has received the teachings from six acharyas. And when Yagyavalkya goes, Janaka asks that I have learned from this particular acharya, this particular aspect. You please tell me. Then he says, this is only ekapadvai brahma. This is only a partial thing what you have learnt.

Then please let me, please tell me. Janaka requests to Yagyavalkya. Then Yagyavalkya says, in that way that is the first Brahmana named as Shadacharya. And second one is called Kurcha Brahmana.

There as we have discussed just now, that from the example aspect of waking, dream and deep sleep and beyond the deep sleep, that is the fourth state, that is Turiya, it will be explained. The only two purpose there in the second Brahmana, what is the purpose? Paraloka and Vimoksha. Parloka is going to the other world and Vimoksha is getting liberation.

So it starts from the grossest waking state, Vishwata Ijasaprajya and then it goes to the subtlest, that is Turiya. In this way you will be seeing and as well here when we start, there also it will be shown. And at the end, what was the mantra of the second Brahmana, if someone remembers?

The last mantra, what is the mantra? abhayam vayajanaka prapto si It is said, now you have reached to the state of fearlessness. Then what was the need to start this third Brahmana? Once you have already solved your purpose, then what is the need, what is the reason to start here? It is said, now we are seeing the Anandgiri and then we will continue with the Bhashya.

Let me announce the page number so you can follow. This is page number 840. In the previous Brahmana, that is what, which one? Second Brahmana, that is Kurcha Brahmana.

By an example of Jagra, Jagra is waking, dream and deep sleep. What happened? The Tatva, whatever was supposed to be understood by Janaka and what was instructed by Yagyavalkya, that was completed, concluded. It is said, Tatvam Nirdharitam. We have decided the Tatvam, that is the supreme aspect.

samprati brāhmaṇa antaraṁ avatārya tasya pūrvena sambandham pratijānite Now what the next brāhmaṇa what we are starting, what is the connection over there is being told by Bhagavan Bhāshyakāra. This particular line is from Ānandagiri. Now the Bhāshya will start. So, the next Kandika which is going to come, the first Kandika, he is saying, So, one fine morning what happens? He goes to the King Janaka.

And who is that King when we talk about Janaka? He is the ruler of Videha. That is why he is called Vaideham.

So the relation is being said, the connection is being said. So this will be the subject topic of this particular Brahman. You see, the Atma, the Self which we are talking about, where does it reflect?

Previously also we have discussed about it. Where did we discuss? Thank you, exactly. In Ajatashtra to Brahmana, what Brahmana is that?

The first Brahmana of the second chapter. There we have discussed where does this self reflect? In the intellect, exactly.

Vijnanamaya. So now there may be a doubt. You see this Bhagwan Bhashyakara is reminding us of the second chapter.

Somebody even after studying all these things, he may have a doubt that the self which is reflected in the intellect is different from the self which is all-pervading consciousness. The supreme consciousness, that may be a doubt. Vijnanamayatma saakshad aparoksad brahma. It is not different from it. Saakshad means it is one and the same.

Aparoksad means, you see, when you talk about the knowledge, one is paroksha jnana and one is aparoksha jnana. Parokshay is what? Indirect knowledge.

And Aparokshay is direct knowledge. So here also you should understand Aparokshad Brahma. There is no difference, not even an iota, not even an...

atom, a single atomic difference is there. The self which is reflected in this intellect, that is which is within and which is all pervading consciousness is not different even. Anumātram api bhedah na kuryād. In Sanskrit it is said, in the scriptures, you should not see a difference even at a subatomic level.

Anumātram api bhedam na kuryād it is said. What will happen? As soon as you see a difference, the whole cycle will start. Dvitiyaadvai bhayam bhavati. You will have fear of the second.

As long as there is no second, there is no reason, there is no cause to fear. But as soon as you see a difference, there remains a second. And as you see a second, there will come the fear of death, fear of birth, etc., So, Aparukshad Brahma Sarvantara Paraeva It is within all the selves. Sarvantara So, Para eva, it is not Apara Brahma.

When going back to Prashnopanishad, if you remember, those who have studied, there were, even in Brihadaranya, even in Chandogya, we discuss about Para Brahma and Apara Brahma. So here what you should understand, the one which is being reflected in the intellect is the highest, Para Brahma eva. You should not mystically understand that it is Apara Brahma. If that happens, then the whole teaching will be failed. So, "para eva" not "aparaha" "nanyo tvasthi drashtra" Then how is it, how will you know about it?

That it is "para brahma eva" and not "aparaha" It is the highest and not the lower Brahman. Then the scriptures themselves say that there is no other being or consciousness which is to be seen. In Sanskrit it is called. Then where does this transmigration come from? It's very easy. In day to day life are you experiencing transmigration or not?

If someone is not experiencing, the class is not for them. They are already Jeevan Mukta. Yes. So if someone is experiencing the transmigration, where does it come from?

So this is being said, "parau paadi nimitta ha sansaaraha" "parah" is what? "agyana" Different from "gyana", different from the "atman". That is called "para".

"Para" should not be considered here higher. Para means different, distinct from the Gyana, distinct from the Atman. Upadik nimittah.

Upadi means the limitation. Just now as we have spoken, the redness which is reflected in the crystal is not of the nature of the crystal, but it is coming from either the red hibiscus flower or the red cloth. So that is called para upadimittah sansaro.

Here four examples are being given by Bhagwan Bhashyakaraha. Anand Giri will be explaining transmigration is of many natures. So examples are also of very many natures. It says Yatha, just like when you see Rajjo, Rajjo is called the rope.

Ushara, Ushara is called the barren land or sand. Shuktika, silver pearl or mother pearl. And Gagana, Gagana is the sky. These four are the examples. What do you see because of the ignorance?

You see When I tell you, you will feel that, yes, what Swamiji is saying is true. There was never a change in this four, but because of our own ignorance, we were seeing a snake on the rope. You see, there is a twilight and if there is a piece of rope, it's there and you are crossing through. The snake is already in your mind. It has not come from somewhere else.

What happens? You superimpose the snake on the rope because of the ignorance. The rope is not clearly seen because of the twilight. What happens?

You are superimposing the snake on the rope. Is there any change in the rope when you have superimposed the snake? Does the rope in reality, in empirical reality, does the rope become snake?

No. Where did that snake come from? It has come from the mind because of the ignorance. Ignorance of what?

Ignorance of the real form of the rope. What was the reason of the ignorance? Because there was no proper light, there was twilight.

As soon as you have a fear in the mind and you are carrying a torch or a battery, you put there and then you say, oh, this is just a rope. I was afraid without any reason. There was no cause for me to be afraid. to fear. What happened?

The superimposition was negated. What has happened? The rope in its original form, you are seeing it. But during a period when you are seeing a snope, there was no change in the rope.

After the period when the superimposition was negated, the snake was negated, there is no change in the rope. So it is only because of the superimposition, that is the limitation, that is 'upadhi'. It is coming out of ignorance. 'Paraupadhi'. This is the first example.

In the same way, 'ooshara', barren land or sand, when you are completely thirsty and when you are walking in the desert, what happens? Even though there is no water, what will happen? You will see a mirage, that there is a water.

And that's how a person goes on walking. Oh, it's there, it's there, but there is never. So that is the second example.

Then, Shuktika. Shuktika is the mother pearl. When you are walking on the beach, sometimes what... You see, each and everything has a reason. First one was, there was no proper light.

Second one was the thirst. Third one is the greed. You see when you are walking on the beach, there is a mother pearl. But what?

There is a greed in the mind. So what will happen? It will feel like it's a silver because of the shining.

But when you lift it, you will say, oh this is just a mother pearl. And the fourth one is Gagana. Gagana is sky.

You are seeing the blueness in the sky. Each and everybody, the science student knows that there is no blueness in the sky. It is only being reflected.

That is also coming only because of this. And it is said, in other Upanishads it is said, that when you see during the daytime when the sun is very hot, and when you are not directly seeing towards the sun, but when you are seeing in the sky, after few moments you will see that there are some figures which are running in the sky, you will see a chariot, you are seeing human beings, and it is all called Gandharvanagara in Sanskrit it is called. Just like there is a whole city, You are seeing the figures and all those things.

When you see for a moment, few moments in the sky, this is all, it's only because of the ignorance, it's only because of what limitations, but in actual reality, this do not remain.
